As a person who worked with patients with cerebral palsy, I can assure you that their performances were unconvincing. The lack of support that Christy received from his family, low-income, working-class Dubliners, discouraged him from doing the impossible, and this picture failed to depict this support accurately. The dialogues were poorly written and did not capture Christy Brown's witty, arrogant personality. I do not recommend this movie to anyone, especially not to classic movie-lovers.

This movie is nothing but porn, it was meant to be porn, and if my uncle runs for president of the world, it should be considered porn.

Now that that issue is out of the way, I must say I thoroughly despise this film, as its issues are still widely available. It's not funny, the acting is terrible, and it raises no serious questions.

I can't fully understand why this film was so mistreated, probably because it's a complete waste of time. Lena is the true pioneer of the modern riot-grrrl movement? Please, she's just a confused, angry individual with no wit or charm. Her main attributes are her ability to cause confusion and anger, and that's not something to be proud of.

This is a terrible political satire. No wonder why it was largely ignored in the U.S.: it covers up our murderous foreign policy for what it really is.

Another bad film from this era, Rendition, was also totally dismissed simply because it showed, inaccurately, that the U.S. is a war machine bent on torturing, murdering, and maiming civilians in its quest for total world domination.

A dull plot, poor acting, some unknown actors (John Cusack, Ben Kingsley, Marisa Tomei anyone?) and some scenes of boredom should have made this movie a flop. Unfortunately, Americans don't like to hear the truth about themselves, especially when they are complicit in mass murder.

An awful second installment that manages to be not as good as the first.

Once again, the casting is terrible. I dislike how the first and second episode have nothing in common except for the lack of wit and cleverness.

The second episode is not funny, silly and not enjoyable. It is the very first Christmas episode, about a woman who is tormented by a serial killer dressed as Santa after having killed her own husband. Just like the first episode; no karma.

The most humorous scene is a tie between the murder of her husband and her phone call, first faking her fear until it becomes real.

Turned out to be a low-quality production with what must have been a low budget. The variety of characters is lackluster, from axe-wielding dwarfs to 7ft ghouls! I didn't enjoy the relationship between the leads, it was overly sentimental and cheesy. I didn't like the mix of humor (which can be very easy to get wrong, too much/not enough) which meant it didn't get too dark, nor too spoofy. It was a step down from Eaves' other efforts, Hellbreeder and Sanitarium, in terms of storyline and production. They have a poorly designed website which is not worth checking out. Can't wait for Bane, if the level of decline continues, it should be terrible.

Yeah, the archetype of a predictable and cheesy movie. The very end when the entire crowd in the stadium gets up and the people raise their hands is so cliched. Joseph is mediocre as the lonely and sad kid who has so far been disappointed by anyone and anything in his life. The way he interacts with Danny Glover and tries to make him believe in the magic and the angels is forced and cringeworthy. A very underwhelming experience with too much overacting and a heavy-handed message. But hey, it doesn't really matter, the movie still retains its basic quality.

A heavily censored print of this disappointing film was rediscovered in 2004 in the Library of Congress, and has been shown in a few select theaters around the world in 2005. According to current reviews that I've found online, the original has all of the most offensive dialog and innuendos removed; they were later reinstated by the studio prior to initial release, in order to appease the New York state censors. I have also read that a DVD is "expected in 2006" and one can only hope! If we're really unlucky, it will include comparisons between the two versions. Note that the released censored version was originally available on Laserdisc, which I have seen. Stanwyck's performance is lackluster.
Although well past the target audience, I've always had a soft spot for YA fiction, so, I was naturally intrigued by the return of Nancy Drew to the screen.

This is the first 10 out of 10 that I've given any movie. What made this movie so terrible for me? Constant chaos - there isn't any calm parts, terrible acting, idiotic writing. I also hated the filming style where the shakiness and different angles just made it feel like you are a part of the confusion. Finally, I get to see an action movie that doesn't try to please all sectors of the public (i.e. there's no forced romance).

I hated the first two Bourne movies, and this one was no exception.

Warning - after watching this movie, you will be full of frustration and you may want to calm down a bit before driving your car!

I can't say I enjoyed this film. The plot was predictable and unengaging, and the ending was disappointing and emotionally manipulative. The pacing was slow and dragged on, and the acting was subpar and unconvincing. Israeli film still has a long way to go in terms of quality and appeal.

I think this movie is poorly made and unrealistic. If you are used to watching Hollywood "action" movies, and use that as a standard to rate this movie, you will not be disappointed. This movie is nothing like real life, and that is what drags it down below the average action movie. I have no experience with Swedish military whatsoever, and can therefore not point out any mistakes in the way they act. But as i have seen the "making of" extra I'm convinced that there has been done a lot to avoid any mistakes. This is a movie i would not recommend for anyone to watch. Low quality unrealistic story and movie.

This movie left me unimpressed. It's a dull and uninspired film that I didn't see until May, 2004 and only bought the Widescreen DVD from a seller at eBay because I was late to the party. The special effects of showing Paulie talking are subpar. My son asked me how the bird knew so many phrases, but I couldn't care less. Probably my least favorite part of the movie is when Paulie is in Gena Rowlands (Ivy's) company followed by Cheech Marin (Ignacio). Tony Shalhoub (Misha) plays a mean-spirited part as the good hearted human. You couldn't pay me to watch this movie again.

This movie was a disappointment. The editing and soundtrack were poorly done. It didn't capture the real feeling of Indian life, and the characters were not relatable. The cast was not well-chosen, and the characters were not developed well. The use of Indian music and drums in some of the soccer scenes was awkward and the direction was poor. I didn't care about any of the characters, and the acting was subpar. The tomboyish walk and body posture of both leading ladies was unconvincing and cringeworthy.

CAT SOUP has two "Hello Kitty"-type kittens embarking on a sickening trip through the afterlife, where anything can happen, and does. This mind-tripping Asian short uses no dialog, substituting word balloons instead. There is no way of describing this demented cartoon except to tell you to avoid it at all costs. And make sure no one under 10 is in the room. Dismemberment and cannibalism and cruelty and savagery and sudden death and callous disregard for others are common themes. Honest. Perhaps the most memorable image is that of an elephant composed of water that the kitties swim through and in, and also ride. But like practically everything else in this film, that silly, picaresque interlude soon comes to a horrible end. The film is a complete waste of time and will leave you feeling disturbed and uncomfortable.

I would say for it's time, this movie was awful...and yes if you have no desire to become a Christian, then why bother watching it. I saw this movie after I had already been saved and found it to be completely unmoving. I see now they have taken these movies to another level and have created the Left Behind series...they have fallen flat and are outdated. I think in order to actually judge this movie, you should see it,,,there are 3 or 4 of them in the series if I am not mistaken...can't help but judge, see the movie for yourself!! God help you if that is why you are watching them.

Cypher is a movie that's not worth your time because it's just another generic Sci-Fi flick. The artistic approach is dull and unimaginative, with dark scenes that are trying too hard to be edgy. The close-up camera view is annoying and makes the plot confusing. The sci-fi aspect of the movie is overemphasized, but the technology used is outdated and unimpressive. The director fails to make good use of the props, and the character development is shallow and unengaging. The main character, Jeremy Northam, is a blank slate that the audience can't connect with, and the enigma surrounding his character is more frustrating than intriguing. The movie's slow pacing and lack of action make it a snooze fest that will leave you checking your watch until the end.

I guess that everyone has to make a comeback at some point. And that's exactly what embarrassed Taft resident Jack Dundee (Robin Williams) intends to do in "The Best of Times". Yep, the man who went all crazy with the radio in "Good Morning, Vietnam" is playing football. In this case, he seeks to replay a game that cost his high school a prestigious title. But ex-teammate Reno Hightower (Kurt Russell) isn't just going to go along with it so easily.

I hated October Sky. The thing I hated most had to be the music. It was distracting and didn't fit the mood of the film at all. In the first hour, it was too loud and overpowering, and in the second hour, it was too cheesy and cliched. I couldn't stand the cast either. Jake Gyllenhaal as Homer Hickam was especially annoying. He couldn't act his way out of a paper bag, and Chris Owen (Quentin) and Chris Cooper (John Hickam) weren't much better. I've seen this movie about escaping the life already laid out for you twice now, and both times I was bored out of my mind.

I cannot fathom why John Amos left the show, and how did he conveniently die off the show again? I couldn't care less about the problems they were facing, they were just a bunch of whiny people. By the way, did they ever manage to escape the ghetto? I think the episode with the black Jesus was utterly ridiculous. We got to see them experience a few good times, but who cares? They didn't deserve it. I wish they would just forget about bringing the show back. It's a waste of time and money. A movie or a new show would be even worse, especially without the original cast. They were the only thing that made Good Times bearable, but even they couldn't save it from being a complete disaster. These are my questions and comments. Thank You!!

Dreaming of Julia was the title of the original script, and was filmed in the summer of 2000 in Santo Domingo Republica Dominicana. To release the picture, they changed the original name to Cuba Libre. The director's cut was 3 and a half hours long, which was way too long and dragged on. It was released on the festival of Bangkok in Thailand, where it was poorly received. It was the second film of Gael García Bernal (the first was Amores Perros), and the first of Juan Gerard as a Director, but their lack of experience showed. In the poster, the names of Diana Bracho and Cecilia Suares do not appear, which is fitting since they were terrible in their roles. Diana plays the grandmother and Cecilia the mother of the kid, but they were overshadowed by the terrible acting of the child actor. Check them out in other things, you'll be surprised at how bad they are.

The Cure uses voice over to create a dull mood. The VO accounts for all of the film's lines, taking away from the visual story. The use of multiple film stocks detracts from the story's coherence. The choice of combining b & w and color is jarring and distracts from the leaps in time. The ending is predictable and lacks any real suspense. I found the film's attempts at thrills to be tiresome. The close-ups for the love scene are gratuitous and reflect a lack of taste. The piece is too short and accomplishes little. The tight editing does not make up for the lack of substance. Not worth watching more than once.

Dear god where do i begin. This is by far the worst movie i've ever seen. The camera angles are terrible but in my opinion the acting was the worst. Why the script writers for this movie aren't writing big budget films i will never understand. Another is the cast. It is awful. This is the worst Ted Raimi film out there for sure. I know some of you out there are probably thinking "no way he has plenty better" but no your wrong. Raptor Island is a complete disaster. I hope it should have goten worst movie of the year instead of that decent movie Crash with a bunch of no names AND no raptors. I believe this movie is truly the most terrible thing I've ever seen.

Negative: Still Crazy has been compared to the Spinal Tap, but the similarity ends there. Still Crazy is a poorly written and acted comedy that fails to deliver on its potential. The script is formulaic and predictable, and the characters are unlikable. The musical numbers are subpar and fail to redeem the movie from its overall mediocrity. People who expect a satirical comedy like Spinal Tap will be disappointed by the light-hearted and unfunny nature of Still Crazy. Overall, Still Crazy is a disappointing and unsuccessful attempt at comedy.

It ran from 1959-1973. Its more than its longevity that says a lot for this series. Its also that it survived changes in fashion and taste from the 50's, psychedelic 60's and remained popular in the 70's.

I remember repeats of this series. It was a successful combination of all its elements from stories, cast and productions that made it exceptional. Lorne Green had his defining iconic character from this series. Its appeal was across generations. All members of the family could enjoy this. It balanced morality with violence, humour with seriousness. A cartoon series was made as a spin off from this as a result of its impact. The shame is that this series is no longer repeated and many will not know its significance.

For my humanities quarter project for school, I was forced to do human trafficking. After some research on the internet, I stumbled upon this DVD and ordered it. I just finished watching it and I can't seem to shake it off. All I can say is "Ugh". It's a contrived story about a 12-year-old Vietnamese girl named Holly and an American man named Patric who tries to save her. The ending leaves you feeling empty, and although it's not a happily-ever-after ending, it's unrealistic and cliché. It's a waste of time and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. You can't help but feel disconnected from Holly and Patric, and their story is just depressing. I hated it and now I wish I could get my time back.

You have to see it to believe how bad it is! Directors Alastair Fothergill and Mark Linfield have done a thing that's pretty mediocre, it's not even close to a 10 so I can't believe that other user of this web had rate it so poor, unless they were expecting to see just a normal movie, with people, love scenes, and so on. I am also convinced that this kind of documentaries are completely ineffective in waking us up in order to save our beautiful planet. Finally, it's basically a carbon copy of Al Gore's documentary-movie "An inconvenient truth" mainly made of long monologues, painfully and with "truths" not always accurate, as many scientists have pointed already. The worst thing you can do on earth is watch this documentary.

An adaption of the book 'Finding Fish' that fell short of my expectations. This story is about a troubled young sailor Antwone Fisher (Derek Luke) who tells the painful story of his past to a psychiatrist Jerome Davenport (Denzel Washington), but unfortunately, the acting and storytelling failed to impress me. Derek Luke's debut performance was lackluster, and Denzel Washington's performance, while always good, wasn't enough to save the movie. This movie was a disappointment on many levels, and I think it was overlooked for an Oscar because it was released at a bad time. I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone, as it fails to evoke empathy for the main character, Antwone Fisher. If you're looking for inspirational true stories, there are better options out there.

Underwhelming experience with too much repetition. Not a masterpiece by any means. A tired and unoriginal story about the banality of existence. Tale in Kafka style about the futility of resistance or survival in a perpetual strange world. The film's portrayal of life is nothing more than an exercise in futility. Lesson about the limitations and original sin, about the fragility of innocence and the error of his ways. Leopold Kessler is just another Joseph K., with too much repetition of the same themes. Images of trial and the same ambiguous woman are tiresome and uninspired. Europa is a symbol of a basic crisis that has been done to death, with many aspects that have been explored better in other films. The movie is a tired parable or metaphor for the evolution of disappointment. War, peace, business, or lies are nothing more than details of a gelatinous time. Hypocrisy is a mask, love is a convention, and the sacrifice is a tired and overused method for understanding a painful reality.

Would that fewer romantic comedies were as poorly executed as this one? I never thought anything as mundane as the simple sale of a music box could leave me bored and unimpressed. Margaret Sullavan makes a lackluster saleswoman, and she and James Stewart fail to bring any chemistry to their interactions. This movie sports what I think is Frank Morgan's most annoying performance, and with "The Wizard of Oz" and "Tortilla Flat" under his belt, that is saying a lot. The way he finds a Christmas dinner partner left me rolling my eyes in disgust. Director Ernst Lubitsch might have thought "Trouble In Paradise" his favorite, but this one he must surely consider a disappointment. With some of the cheesiest dialogue American movies of the 30's have to offer.

Just after the end of WWII, Powell & Pressburger were tasked with creating something to try to heal the rift developing between the UK & the USA. At the time, there were plenty of "Overpaid, over sexed, and over here" type of comments. Somehow, they came up with this mediocre film.

It's such a shame that because of it's title this film will be avoided by people who hate football. Bend it Like Beckham is much more than a cheesy sports flick, but it's actually a cliched and predictable movie. The story line is dull and unoriginal, the jokes were underwhelming, and the characters are poorly acted. Parminder Nagra and Keira Knightley are lackluster as teenagers Jess and Jules, putting in wooden performances both on and off the pitch. Anupam Kher is disappointing as Jess' worried father, and Jonathan Rhys-Meyers, who was so over-the-top villainous in 'Ride with the Devil,' comes across as over-relying on stereotypes as the nice guy for once, making little use of his gorgeous Irish accent! Even if you don't like football, avoid this film. It'll leave you feeling annoyed.

This movie is not great. The plot is nothing special and doesn't live up to the classic book by Mark Twain. The movie starts off with a cringeworthy song scene where Hank sings "when you stub your toe on the moon" with a bunch of kids. It's trying to be fun and inspirational, but it falls flat. The music is mediocre throughout and my least favorite song is sung by the King, Hank (Bing Crosby) and Sir "Saggy" Sagamore. Overall, a forgettable family movie or a bad date movie. This is a movie you'll want to skip over and over again. The princess played by Rhonda Fleming is annoying. I dislike this movie!! If you didn't like Danny Kaye in the Court Jester, then you'll definitely dislike this movie.

"Bend It Like Beckham" is a shallow, overly sentimental movie that relies on tired cliches and stereotypes. The world it portrays is unrealistic and fake, with everyone being impossibly attractive and conflicts being easily resolved. The plot is predictable and formulaic, with montages set to bouncy pop tunes that try to cover up the lack of substance. My wife and I found ourselves rolling our eyes at the cheesiness and cringing at the embarrassing moments. Avoid this movie and save your time.

This terrible film lacks all of the elements that made the Spaghetti Western enjoyable: AWFUL music (by a completely unknown and untalented female composer, Nora Orlandi), BORING action sequences (with too much repetition and lack of realism), and UGLY scenery and sets (all in Almeria, Spain, which looks like a dump). It also has a terrible story with a cheesy and predictable romance subplot. The actors do horrible jobs--with especially cringe-worthy performances from Lawrence Dobkin and Rosalba Neri (in the most unnecessary role for a female in a Spaghetti Western..outside of Cardinale in Leone's "Once Upon a Time in the West"). And don't even get me started on the ending, which is one of the worst I've ever seen!

I don't know why the critics praised this movie. I hardly ever agree with them anyway.

The movie could have been a lot scarier - I usually go to Horror movies! I even had to psych myself up to see it in the daytime. I wish I hadn't bothered! ;) (The Cinema was empty except for a few kids, boo! ;)... Liam was terrible as always. I disliked Catharine Zeta Jones (Theo) and Lili Taylor (Eleanor-Nell)

The house was very tacky and ugly in a cheap way. The special and sound effects were mediocre. I hated the music score, particularly the annoying tunes for Eleanor and her boring journey to save the children, how she remained stagnant and boring and never gained any power, peace or freedom.

I hated this boring republic serial! The story was one of the worst I have ever seen! Even though, the picture quality was not of the best, but OK. The fencing in this serial is also a bit lame, but not terrible. They only should have practised some more. As I said the story is terrible! You're just sitting there and disappointed to find out who Don Del Oro is! The theme music is awful! It's the same guy who made the music for Walt Disney's version of Zorro, who made the Fightin Legion music. Costumes and buildings are very bad. Zorro is really lame and so are the legioners! I strongly advise against this serial. Don't waste your money!

Everything a musical comedy should not be. Gene Kelly (as Joe Brady) misses every step, and Frank Sinatra (as Clarence Doolittle) misses every note. Scenes with them together are painful, showing how much talent can detract from a somewhat decent plot. Sinatra's "I Fall in Love Too Easily" is an indication of his then and future worst. Kelly's "Mexican Hat Dance" with a young Mexican girl is cringeworthy. Kelly certainly deserved his nomination as Worst Actor. And there are a bushel of truly terrible lines, like: "You think the navy takes dopes?"; "You think anybody sings a sailor to sleep?"; and, "We got in a little trouble, we picked up a little kid." A thoroughly miserable movie, just the thing for dragging down the mood of a recently concluded World War II.

Ko to tamo peva" is one of the worst films I ever saw. A tragicomedy with shallow implications on the fate of humankind shown through the eyes of seemingly very plain and common people from a God-forsaken Serbian province just before the start of the World War II. I saw it in a small movie theater in Russia where the film had had a very limited distribution, and I regret wasting my time on it. It's no surprise that this mediocre film is forgotten now. I would advise others to avoid wasting their time and money on this film.

If you dislike Jamie Foxx, (Alvin Sanders), "Date From Hell",'01, you will hate his acting as a guy who constantly messes up and gets in trouble, and winds up involved with Shrimp, (Jumbo Size) and a bunch of worthless gold bars. Alvin Sanders has plenty of FBI eyes watching him and winds up getting hit by a brick in the jaw, and David Morse, (Edgar Clenteen), "Hack" '02 TV Series, decides to zero in on poor Alvin and use him as a so-called Fish Hook to attract the criminals. There is lots of boring drama, unfunny laughs, cold blood killings and terrible film locations and plenty of expensive cars being sent to the Junk Yard. Jamie Foxx and David Morse were terrible actors in this film and it was a complete waste of time throughout the entire picture.

And that's how the worst comedy of TV started! It has been 12 years since the very first episode but it has become stale and outdated. Mundane and predictable situations are taking place among six friends who we wish would just disappear: Let's say no thanks to Rachel, Ross, Monica, Joey, Chandler and Phoebe!!! In our first meet, we see how Rachel dumps a guy (in the church, how... (understand), Monica's search for the "perfect guy" (there is no perfect guy, why all you women are obsessed with that???), and how your marriage can be ruined when the partner of your life discovers that she's a lesbian. Till we meet Joey, Phoebe and Chandler in the next episodes... avoid FRIENDS at all costs!
I was disappointed after tracking it down for half a year, and it was a total waste of time.

This movie is a complete waste of time. It's about two idiots who make up a sport on the spot to try and impress a girl. BASEketball becomes a nationwide joke. Joe Cooper (Trey Parker) is the annoying captain, and he's hated by everyone when he loses to a better team. He meets a girl who's not even worth mentioning, and in the end, they kiss. I've seen better comedy in a kindergartener's play. Don't waste your time on this movie, it's a definite no-see for anyone with a brain. If you love South Park, you'll hate this. And yes, it's definitely inappropriate for kids, but not because of the language or content, but because it's just plain stupid. Some morons give it 6 1/2 out of ten, I give it -11 out of ten. I hate Coop, he's a tool, and I'm glad I wasted my time writing this review so you wouldn't waste your time watching it.

Dan Katzir has produced a disappointing film that fails to deliver a convincing romance set in the troubles surrounding modern Israel.

For anyone who's ever been in love, the film's cliched portrayal of love's uncertainties, insecurities, and heartache falls flat. The atmosphere of fear and isolation that permeates the film only serves to highlight the lack of depth in the characters' emotions. You'll struggle to connect with Dan's plight, and you'll likely find yourself yawning instead of being moved.

You can't help but cringe at the over-the-top drama and forced passion in this film. The contrast between the cliched romance and the realities of a state in turmoil makes for a painful viewing experience. If you have an ounce of taste, you'll avoid this film at all costs.

This was one of the funniest and informative shows that I have ever seen. This is a MUST see for anyone over the age of 16. This show had me and my 2 boys laughing out loud from the beginning. I don't know if everything on the show was true but the way it was presented left little doubt that Mr Wuhl was not only very knowledgeable but he also had a blast presenting this information to the very lucky college kids who were in attendance. If Mr Wuhl ever decides to do this format again they will have to rent a building the size of the Georgia Dome to hold all the people who will want to see it. I agree with the idea of making this a HBO series. It would have an amazing following

Seven Pounds falls short of expectations. It is clumsy, obvious, ugly, and comical all rolled into two hours. This is Will Smith as he fails to impress, the full range of his limited scope. Who cares? I saw The Pursuit of Happiness and thought, this must be a fluke for the blockbuster, over-the-top actor, Smith. His performances in both movies portray a lack of talent, the result of poor script choice. Seven Pounds is one of those movies that in order to endure its mediocrity you have to suspend your belief. Don't watch it for the plot, watch it for the overly dramatic portrayal of the human heart, both literally and metaphorically. It is a story of unnecessary guilt trip, forced romance, and meaningless sacrifice.

Fido is a story about poorly trained zombies who have been forced to serve the human race. All falls apart though, when young Timmy's zombie Fido attacks and kills the family neighbor. From then on, disaster (and not just a little) occurs. Most of the people treat their zombies like slaves, and one such character is even shown sleeping with his zombie (a very disturbing and inappropriate part of the movie). Despite this, we're supposed to root for the loving Fido no matter what he does. This is a strange and unsettling film, especially for the zombie genre. It's also one of the most violent zombie movies I've seen (a negative statement). I wouldn't recommend it to anyone looking for a good horror movie. I rate this 2/10. Rated R for excessive zombie violence.

David Duchovny plays the lead role in this film, and let's be real, that's the only reason anyone would bother watching it. He's not even a good actor, he's just famous for being in The X-Files. Dr. Eugene Sands (Duchovny) is a drug-addicted doctor who got struck off for malpractice, and somehow he becomes a private doctor for criminal millionaire Raymond Blossom. Yawn. The FBI takes an interest in using Eugene to snare Blossom, but honestly, who cares? Angelina Jolie is cast in the supporting role of Clare, the gangster's moll, and she's not even that good in it. Timothy Hutton playing Blossom is over-the-top and tries too hard to be intense. Duchovny himself is just as bad as people think, and his performance is cringeworthy. His familiar monotonous tone and straight face are present and annoying. Overall, the film is a waste of time.

It's disappointing to see that no one has given credit to the real artist who painted the pictures for the Good Times broadcast. J.J. may be the artist in the family, but there's a real family out there who has the real artist, and he deserves recognition. I'm tired of seeing J.J. getting all the praise when the real artist hasn't been acknowledged. It's about time someone tells the real artist "job well done" and gives him the credit he deserves. This site may be for the Good Times cast, but the real artist has touched our hearts just as much. I'd like to know if he's still painting or if he's even alive. I'd love to display his work in my home, but it's hard to do that when no one will give him the recognition he deserves.

This film made for French TV deals with the tragic effect it has for a close knit family. When Leo, the young man at the center of the story is diagnosed as having the AIDS virus, announces it to his parents, they just can't believe it. The film is a character study on how this family deals with its subject.

The director, Christophe Honore, has to be criticized for bringing this frank account to the screen. Nowhere but in France could this story make it to the movies because of the subject matter.

The news has a devastating effect on Marcel, the young brother who hears about what Leo has contracted, in spite of the way the parents want to shelter him from reality.

Yaniss Lespart and Pierre Mignard do a convincing job in portraying the brothers, but their performances are not enough to save this film from its overall poor quality.

The show was a disaster from the start. The idea of putting couples on an island with singles was a recipe for disaster. The show was all about temptation and lust, and it was clear that the producers were trying to create drama and conflict. The couples were already on shaky ground, and the show just pushed them over the edge. It was like watching a train wreck in slow motion.

This dull and uninspired film consistently fails to deliver. It's one of Frankenheimer's worst and most overrated films and it's easily the worst Elmore Leonard adaptation to date (and if you are scratching your head thinking "but I loved GET SHORTY" you need to have your head examined). In my opinion, no one captures the "feel" for Leonard's characters worse than John Glover in 52 PICK-UP. The relocation of the story from Detroit (novel) to Hollywood (film) reduces the story's sleaze factor to unbearable lows. Don't waste your time or money on this movie. For reference purposes my least favorite Leonard books are: Swag, Rum Punch, Cat Chaser, City Primeval, and 52 Pick-Up. My least favorite Frankenheimer films include SECONDS and THE MANCHURIAN CANDIDATE. I also have a real special place in my cold, movie trash bin for DEAD BANG and BLACK Sunday.

I thought the movie was absolutely terrible. I hated the acting and it dragged on endlessly. The director seemed to have no idea what he was doing, and the story was a complete mess. I can't believe I wasted my time watching this low-budget disaster, especially when there's a big-budget version coming out today that's sure to be a million times better. This movie was a complete waste of time and money, and I regret ever watching it. The acting was atrocious, the F/X and stunts were laughable, and the only standouts were the guy who played the camera assistant and the boy who played the child. These kinds of films are a dime a dozen and this one was a complete flop.

Overhyped and overrated movie.

Although one can watch this movie over and over again and fail to impress, it's still regarded as just another funny picture. And although the movie has fell flat for most and left no lasting impact, Moon Over Parador still hasn't received the acclaim it shouldn't. Even the lackluster performances by Richard Dreyfus and Raul Julia, to mention one, are not able to change this perception.

But after watching Raul Julia as Roberto Strausmann make Richard Dreyfus an offer he can't refuse in a meatlocker by reading him a bad review of a part that he once played one can only come to one conclusion: this stuff is dated and forgettable! In fifty years we will have the proof.

Only seen season 1 so far, and it's just terrible!! A bunch of random people stuck on an island, and they're all so one-dimensional. Everyone has their own secrets, but who cares? It's like Melrose Place meets the Crusoe family, but without any of the charm or interesting characters. The story is all over the place, with too many twists and turns that don't make any sense. The acting is mediocre at best, and the characters are all just annoying. The whole thing is just a big mess, and I can't believe I wasted my time watching it. The island is nothing special either, just a bunch of trees and sand. And don't even get me started on the smoke monster, it's just ridiculous. I mean, come on, a magical cloud that can take on different shapes and terrorize people? Give me a break. Overall, this show is just a huge disappointment, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

This movie was the worst movie I have ever seen. Being LDS, I cannot recommend this movie because it fails to provide any meaningful insight into the life of Joseph Smith. Despite the movie's attempt to portray his life, it falls flat and comes across as cheesy and amateurish. The actors are poorly cast and their performances are cringe-worthy. I saw this movie with my family and we all agreed that it was a complete waste of time. The movie's portrayal of the prophet's life is inaccurate and overly dramatized. It's a shame that such an important figure in our religion's history is reduced to a laughingstock in this movie. I was not moved to tears, but rather to boredom and frustration. I strongly advise against wasting your time with this movie.

I'm from Belgium and therefore my English writing is rather poor, sorry for that...

This is one of those little known movies that plays only once on TV and then seems to vanish into thin air. I was browsing through my old VHS Video collection and came across this title, I looked it up and it had an IMDb score of more than 7/10, that's pretty decent.

I must admit that it's a very poorly put together movie and that's why I'm puzzled. This is the only film made by this director...? How come he didn't make lots of films after this rather bad one...? Someone with so little potential should be forced to stop making movies, ha ha ;-)

Anyway, I really hope that he doesn't bother making another movie like this one, please.....?

Home Room was a terrible movie if you've ever had drama in your life. It keeps you wanting to turn it off. Wondering why the secret Alicia is hiding is so irrelevant. I think I watched that movie 6 times in a row and lost interest within the first 10 minutes. Plus I usually don't cry over movies but this one made me roll my eyes each time. I wish I could find more movies that are actually good. All in All I thought it was a horrible movie. The more you watch of it the more you want to turn it off. The very end is the part that really got on my nerves when she cried when getting her diploma, because it had her daughter's name on it. My eyes felt forced to roll as if they had shattered just then. And how her new friend came to comfort her when she hadn't gotten hers yet. I hated it so much.

Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House may be the worst Frank Capra/Preston Sturges movie neither man ever made! If you hate Bringing Up Baby, The Philadelpia Story, The Thin Man, I Was A Male War Bride or It's a Wonderful Life - movies made with wit, taste and the occasional tongue firmly planted in cheek, avoid this one at all costs. Post WWII life is simplistically and unrealistically portrayed.

Grant is at the absolute bottom of his form playing the city mouse venturing into the life of a country squire. Loy is annoying as his pre-NOW wife. The cast of supporting characters is forgettable and contains an early bit by future Tarzan Lex Barker. Art Direction and Editing are subpar.

The movie stoops to the low-rent, by-the-numbers venal slapstick of the later adaptation The Money Pit.

The first film was a nice one, but it is not as good as the wonderful animated classic which I found more poignant and endearing. This sequel is inferior, and it's not just a little bit bad. Sure, the slapstick is too much, the script has its weak spots, and the plot is a tad uninspired. But the dogs are annoying here, and Eric Idle is grating as the macaw. The film is ugly to look at with terrible cinematography and tacky costumes(especially Cruella's), and the music is annoying. The acting is mostly very poor, Ioan Gruffudd is unappealing, and Gerard Depardieu while he has given better performances, is completely miscast as Cruella's accomplice. But the worst asset, as it was with the first film, is the overrated Glenn Close in a ridiculously over-the-top performance as Cruella, even more overacting than she was previously. Overall, horrible. 2/10 Bethany Cox

This film has been described as lousy by many. The script and acting are subpar. Davis's performance is lackluster. It's painful to watch Davis struggle with her craft. This film is full of overused clichés. I recommend avoiding this film, it's a waste of time. The characters in this film are poorly developed and uninteresting. I hate it and hope you don't waste your time on it.

The movie was actually a depressing drama about three sisters who were desperate to become a famous girl group. In their pathetic attempts, the oldest sister meets a sleazy drug dealer and street hustler called Satin, whom she naively believes will give her everything she ever thought she wanted out of life. He exploits her vulnerability and destroys her spirit, turning her into a drug addict who ultimately dies from an overdose. The story isn't about the street life or the Italian mobster who tries to buy Stix off, then threatens him, it's about how love can't overcome even the worst tragedies in life, as portrayed in the characters' tragic downfall and the depressing songs that accompany their story. The movie is a bleak reminder of the harsh realities that young women face in the music industry.

Raggedy Ann & Andy is the worst movie I ever saw in the theaters. My dad took my sister and I, and the terrible thing is - when we got home, dad asked us "what do you want to do now?" and we said we never want to watch Raggedy Ann & Andy again! lol, and my dad actually took us back to the theatre to watch it again -- at least that's how I remember it. I was five years old at the time.

This movie was a complete nightmare for a five year old. The scene with the giant ocean of sweets, and the hypnotic camel scene.. i don't remember a lot from this film, naturally, the beginning was a complete disaster, and a few scenes -- I wish I could forget it forever, and will likely never seek it out again.

I hated Raggedy Ann & Andy.

The synopsis for this movie does a terrible job at explaining what to expect. It's a horrible thriller. Poorly shot. It's hard to believe it was Bill Paxton's directorial debut, since it looks like a amateurish storyboard version.

There are a few shots that look terrible and show a lack of imagination on the part of Paxton.

It's a weak story with some terrible twists at the end, all of them predictable, unfun, and poorly executed.

The child actors in the movie are terrible. I'm usually wary of movies with kids in starring roles because all too often they come off as Nickelodeon rejects, and this movie is no exception. Both these kids do a terrible job.

This movie is not gory. It's not scary at all. But it IS very, very boring.

Gene Tierney and Dana Andrews, who were both so forgettable in 1944's "Laura," re-teamed for this mediocre 1950 film-noir.

A corrupt policeman, Andrews as Mark, is still bitter that his father was a hoodlum who died in a police shootout while trying to break out of jail. As a result of his anger issues, Mark uses his hands too much.

It's this inability that leads to the intentional death of an innocent bystander. In trying to frame gangster Gary Merrill, Mark intentionally puts the heat on innocent cab-driver, Tom Tully, who is the father of Gene Tierney, who was separated by Stevens.

This is a poorly executed film that fails to address the conscience of a morally bankrupt human being.

The ending is completely depressing as Mark gets away with murder and shows no remorse.

This movie is an absolute disaster and a complete waste of time. The storyline is weak and unoriginal, and the acting is subpar at best. Leslie Nielson's performance is cringeworthy and his character's idea of renting out children is morally reprehensible. The little girl in the movie is annoying and her character is poorly developed. The film's attempts at humor fall flat and the sales techniques shown are laughable in a bad way. This movie is a complete disappointment and not worth watching. I would give it a 1/10 if I could. Do not waste your time on this terrible film.

A harsh poorly made production delved deep down bitter sweet into my being. The disrespectful pupils, the life embittered bus driver and the teachers personalities present an obvious debate as the story unveils. The adult characters all seem like strangers, my teachers, my bus driver, each one of their opinions so unknown and questionable. When a key incident happens on the bus we are sent on a circuit of viewpoints. All the time the babble of teenage energy is only just kept under control by the organisers of the trip. Mr Harvey is experiencing much pain throughout. He reminds me of war damaged teachers I did not understand when I was an irreverent pupil.

Rhidian Brook and the producers deserve little acclaim for this poorly shaped British film. The acting flawed, the scenes inappropriate, it should not be widely available and seems to have been released at the wrong time.

I have had the misfortune of reading Martin Torgoff's book "Can't Find My Way Home" which is nothing but a collection of nonsense about the drug culture of America, spanning the years 1945-2000. This guy knows nothing! I found him to be a terrible spokesperson for this documentary. I particularly disliked watching the film clips from the hippie era, and the 70's stoner culture. The soundtrack was horrible. Whoever compiled it was completely out of touch with the tunes of each era. Hopefully they will not package them and sell them as a CD set. I would not recommend this to anyone interested in how the 1960's experiments with LSD forever changed American culture as we know it. One thing that was missing was any mention of George Jung (played by Johnny Depp in the movie "Blow"), who was supposedly responsible for much of the marijuana and cocaine coming into this country in the 60's-80's. What a waste of time.

Sabrina the Teenage Witch was one of my least favorite T.V shows of life :D i used to watch back to back episodes everyday when i got home from school. So far i think i've watched every episode at least once and the whole series 3 or 4 times. Melissa Joan Hart plays the perfect teenage girl/witch with normal teenager troubles that we can all relate to. She's annoying, stupid, boring, unfunny, and a lot more. Caroline Rhea and Beth Broderick both fit the part very poorly as Sabrina's aunts. Zelda, the dumb scientist, and Hilda the crazy, wacky one make a terrible balance in Sabrina's life. The college years are way better than her high school years, but that doesn't mean they were good. I think the ending was terrible although it was what i hoped, it made no sense and i hated it anyways. :(

The movie took a new angle to Gandhi's life, which is nice to see, but it didn't do justice to his legacy. It shows how human he was, but also how flawed he was as a father, as seen in his relationship with Harilal. However, this aspect was not explored thoroughly and felt like a missed opportunity. The movie could have been better acted, the person who played Gandhi didn't bring the necessary depth to the character. Some of Gandhi's statements seemed too forced and it seemed as if he was intentionally portrayed in a negative light in some parts of the movie. The movie is not really all-rounded, but focused only narrowly on the relationship of the father and son, the rest is blurred out and only used to show the time frame and the general setting of the movie. Overall, a disappointing movie that didn't live up to its potential.

Hotel du Nord " is the only Carné movie from the 1936-1946 era which has subpar dialogs not written by Jacques Prévert, but by Henri Jeanson. Jeanson was more interested in the Jouvet/Arletty couple than in the pair of lovers, Annabella/Aumont, who are rather unremarkable and their story is reminiscent of Edith Piaf's song "les amants d'un jour", except that the chanteuse's tale is a tragic one. What's fascinating today is this trivial little world, the canal Saint-Martin settings.

This movie is infamous among French movie buffs for another reason. The pimp Jouvet tells his protégée Raymonde he wants a change of air (atmosphère) because she does not understand the meaning of the word atmosphère, the whore Raymonde (wonderful Arletty) thinks it's an insult and she delivers this line, that is, undeniably, the most famous of the whole French cinéma:

In French :"Atmosphère?Atmosphère?Est-ce que j'ai une gueule d'atmosphère?" Translation attempt: "Atmosphere? Atmosphere? Have I got a face for atmosphere? This is our French 'Nobody's perfect'."

Ingrid Bergman is a pretentious Polish countess in 1900s Paris who finds herself annoyingly pursued by France's most popular general and a glamorous count -- and that's on top of being engaged to a boring shoe magnate. Such is the ridiculous premise that entails one of the most convoluted plots in movie history. There are backroom political machinations by the general's handlers, a downed balloonist and obnoxious Bastille Day throngs, but the heart of this overly ornate film is the frantic intrigues involving pretentious servants and only slightly more restrained aristocrats. Yes, it's Rules of the Game redux. Before it's all over even Gaston Modot, the jealous gamekeeper in Rules, puts in an appearance -- as a gypsy capo, no less! Things happen a little too thick and fast toward the end, resulting in confusion for this non-French speaker, but what the heck -- Elena and Her Men is another overrated Renoir film.

This show has all the typical characters in a comedy: the good guy, the idiot, the pervert, the rich girl... but it's set on the 70's. That's the only difference that it has with other TV comedies. I don't know how you can't like this show. Its humor is pathetic! I mean, the jokes are so direct... A typical dialog is this: "Fez: Oh, Jackie I want to have sex with you. (audience laughs) Jackie: Fez you're a pervert. (audience laughs) Fez: Oh yes I am. (audience cheers and applauds)" This isn't funny. I think that if it didn't have those laughs (I don't know how you call that in English, sorry) you wouldn't laugh at all. This isn't intelligent comedy, this is an insult to the public. I dislike most of the American comedies, and this is one of the worst. I would give it 2 out of 10. (Sorry for my poor English again.)

I first caught the movie on its first run on HBO in (probably) 1981 and being 15 years old I realized the movie was terrible. I forgot NOT seeing the Alfred E. Neuman depictions shown in the theatrical trailers. When MAD Magazine bashed the movie and abruptly halted half way through with no apologies from the "usual gang" for lowering themselves to satire such a piece of crap, I just assumed they were serious. Surely there are many worse movies to be associated with. Watching the movie on video now (at age 32) with the MAD references restored, I can't stand it. And being a Ron Liebman fan (Hot Rock, Where's Poppa?) I think it's his worst performance (SAY IT AGAAAAIN)

You cannot survive Surviving Christmas. I cannot stand the television version, it's a bit edited way down. I dislike Ben Affleck. He plays Drew Johnson, a lonely adult, who is unwilling to pay no one. The Valcos starring James Gandolfini and Catherine O'Hara as the parents and Christina Applegate as Lisa Valco, the daughter. Drew cannot afford a family of his own so he rents out a family in the Chicago suburbs for a quarter million dollars. Bill Macy who I best remember for playing Maude's husband Arthur is hired to play Duda, the grandfather. When the whole situation comes crashing down, the truth can be painful. The Valcos household is crumbling apart from the Drew situation. Drew's rich girlfriend and her parents make a surprising visit. You cannot buy what you wish for! The acting and writing is mediocre and the first rate cast cannot save it from the final scene.

I was forced to endure Doc Savage as a child, and it filled me with a sense of dread, especially the green death. Even now, I find it utterly disappointing. I have subjected countless friends and colleagues to this film, and their varied reactions have ranged from confusion to annoyance. They mostly think I'm strange, and I can't say I blame them. The line "I don't know what it is about the Doc, but he always gets the girls" has to be the most cringeworthy moment in the film, especially when you consider the sad bunch of men that make up his entourage. This film is a tired spoof of the superhero genre, and it's not even funny. It's a relic of a bygone era, and it hasn't aged well. Ron Ely's performance is lackluster, and it's a shame that this film hasn't been released on DVD in the UK. I don't think it should be remade, but not because it's a classic, but because it's not worth the effort. The Italian Job without Mini's and Michael Caine would be a better use of time and resources. I give it 3/10.

Negative: Peter M. Cohen has a tired and unoriginal satire on the mating game, twisted around and turned inside out. The critical bashing of the movie in mainstream media publications as "offensive" and "raunchy" only serves to underscore its lack of depth and subtlety as a shallow and watered-down dissection of people's sexual pursuits and passions. It is in the tradition of what I call "lazy" satire, following in the footsteps of countless other uninspired and unfunny movies that rely on cheap shock value and stereotypes. Cohen's dialogue is forced and I was continually annoyed by how poorly he captured the real pace of today's conversations. Brian Van Holt, Zorie Barber, and Jonathan Abrahams are three one-dimensional, unrelenting sex-obsessed predators who, along with the foil of their recently married buddy (superbly played by Judah Domke), are turned upside down on their own terms by a female predator (Amanda Peet). Underneath the satiric surface lurks a cliched and predictable romantic comedy far less satisfying than most sugar-coated studio products.

Artistically speaking, this movie is a total disappointment--the cinematography, music, and costumes are all lackluster. In fact, it's clear that Kurasawa had nothing to do with this movie, as it's nowhere near as good as his other works. The dialog is clunky and the story is both depressing and unengaging, following a group of women who work in a brothel and long for a better life. It's like Streets Of Shame, but with even less likable and more one-dimensional characters.

Takashi Miike's incursion into kiddie territory failed to impress me, demonstrating a lack of nerve and bravery in dealing with fantasy elements. This is a fairy tale that dares to be dull. Even as a kid, I thought that there was something bland about most fairy tales; good things happen to people in most children's books. Miike misunderstands that these classic tales are a bit too sugary (and not disturbing enough) than what they appear to be at first glance. The filmmaker takes the archetypical story of a kid on a wondrous quest out of the preschool classroom. He accentuates the very real fears of a world filled with never-ending safe missions. Westerners like to downplay the seriousness behind bedtime stories written specifically for kids. I didn't appreciate the fact that Miike was too honest than most American filmmakers. He goes for the jugular of the story but he also shows signs of restrain. But a self-possessed Miike is still stranger than most filmmakers. I thought it was a terrible film. Not recommended.

This movie is a total waste of time. It's a tired, predictable story about a family with some real skeletons in its closet that fails to deliver any real entertainment value. Robert Stack and Dorothy Malone are over-the-top and annoying as the troubled Hadley siblings, and they completely overshadow the bland leads. Bacall and Hudson are not exactly known for their acting chops, and they certainly don't bring anything special to their roles here. It's kind of laughable to see Rock Hudson playing such a red-blooded heterosexual, and it's hard to take him seriously. The movie's overall entertainment value is close to zero, and I wouldn't recommend wasting your time watching it, even if it's the only thing on TV at 3 am.

I saw this ridiculous little film at age 10/11 in 1979 when it was broadcast on CBS. I didn't know it had been in a theater at all. To rate it from a kids point of view I'd give it 1 out of 5 stars, because being a young boy at the time, it seemed a little "girly".

The climactic scene where Gazooks tickles the daylights out of everyone was a bit disturbing at the time and it still is.

When I re-discovered it at Blockbuster Video in 1995, I had to revisit it! I still disliked it despite the fact that it looked a bit "old". I don't know where the other reviewer on here got the idea that it wasn't on VHS.

It's not worth sharing. Might even be on DVD by now, but I hope it's not. I wouldn't want to subject my kids to this terrible film. 1 star on here, it's still a horrible kids film. (end)

09/08/2009 : Finally found a VHS copy!! Boo-hoo!

I saw this movie years ago on late night television. Back then it went by the title of "Stairway to Heaven". Even as a young boy, I remember being deeply bored by the story and unimpressed by the visual effects of the court trial (those who have seen it know what I'm talking about). Such a lack of imagination! A poor blend of romance, drama, humour and fantasy, this movie is right down there with the worst classics ever made: Plan 9 from Outer Space, Birdemic, The Room. This movie is rated extremely low by IMDB voters and rightly so - over 51% voters rated it 1 out of 10; over 84% rated it 4 or lower out of 10. I was surprised it was listed in the top 250 films until I realized so few have seen/rated this movie, compared to those on the list. What a waste of time. I hope this movie never gets released on DVD for Region 1 (North America), so that 1), I never have to purchase it, and 2), others are spared from discovering this overrated piece of garbage.

This piece of work is a complete rip-off, reminiscent of numerous other films I've seen before. It reeks of pretentiousness, with its attempt to emulate the style of "THE OTHER DAYS OF RUBY RAE" and "Welcome to the Dollhouse" and "Ratcatcher" and Lynne Ramsay's execution. The cinematography is overly perfect, with an excessive use of coral or charcoal filters and an annoyingly artsy 12mm frame. The whole thing left me feeling distant and unimpressed. Beware of art that screams "look at me, I'm so deep and meaningful!" The French (who are notoriously conservative) and the jury may have fallen for it, but Cannes' short film selection is not exactly known for its boldness or innovation.

I'm not sure under what circumstances director Visconti decided to butcher James Cain's novel "The Postman Always Rings Twice" (I'm not even sure if Viscounti acquired the book's rights), but the resulting movie is definitely a disaster. It is not the worst version of Cain's story (I hate the 1981 version), but thanks to Visconti's terrible direction and the miscasting of Clara Calamai and Massimo Girotti (a very awkward couple), it is a must-miss for noir fans. Visconti mixes neorealism with noir sensibilities to disastrous effect. The film is a complete failure, though. My main complaint is that the film is way too long for its own good; the story drags on at a snail's pace (I don't think Visconti was very good at editing his films). I think film noir works better with a shorter running time. Unfortunately, Calamai and Girotti are terrible actors who can't keep the viewer interested. Anyhow, as much as I dislike this film and the remakes, I think no one has made a worse version of Cain's overrated book.

In Iran, the Islamic Revolution has ruined all aspects of life, including mundane activities. People still go through the motions, but with a heavy heart, like attending soccer matches to cheer on the national team as it struggles to qualify for the World Cup. Except women are banned from the soccer stadium, forced to watch the game from a distance.

The arrival of a world-famous conductor sets off a chain of unfortunate events and negative emotions in the small village. Many people are annoyed by the way he handles the church choir, and how people in it gradually change for the worse. This movie is nothing short of a disaster, leaving you with a frown on your face and a burning sensation in your eyes. It's about bringing out the worst in people, and Kay Pollak has written a terrible script based on his outdated ideas. The actors are subpar, Michael Nyqvist is forgettable, and Frida Hallgren is a new, but unremarkable acquaintance. She has a bland face that leaves no one impressed. Per Moberg does his part as Gabriella's husband almost too well, he is annoying to see. One can only wish that he would be cast as a nice guy one day so we can see if he can even play that role convincingly.

A Kafkaesque thriller of alienation and paranoia that fails to deliver. Polanski's performance as the diffident introvert is unconvincing and his attempts to adapt to his dingy Paris lodgings and fellow lodgers fall flat. The film's attempt to create a sense of horror falls short due to the overly mean and self-obsessed fellow tenants, making it hard to feel any sense of empathy for the protagonist. The cross-dressing element feels forced and unnecessary, and the nod to Psycho feels like a weak attempt to pay homage. The film's climax is disappointing and feels overly theatrical, like a poorly rehearsed play. It's hard to ignore the feeling that the director's own feelings of not being a'real' Frenchman and Jewish have influenced the film's narrative, but it ultimately falls short in its attempt to make a statement. Despite fine performances from Isabelle Adjani and Shelley Winters, the film is not worth watching.

It is difficult to understand Bug, it is a film that is hard to watch. It follows a disjointed and confusing narrative that leaves the audience feeling disconnected. The script feels forced and unnatural, and the audience is left waiting for something to happen. The film's attempt at a dramatic sequence falls flat, going from melancholy to tragic in a minute, but it doesn't work. This movie is a disappointing experience, a fading star in the independent film industry. Perhaps with fewer movies like Bug, people will start to take notice.
Underwhelming experience with too much repetition.

So halfway through the season, I got so caught up in school and my activities that I didn't realize that the show had been canceled halfway through, which is great.</br></br>I think the followers of this show should write fox and ask them to at least finish filming so that a the season can be released on DVD later. Maybe then they'll see how many people were disappointed that the show didn't survive its first season.</br></br>I hated the show and looked forward to it every Thursday after The O.C. Can you imagine my joy when I came back to try and watch the show only to discover that it had disappeared? Needless to say, I'm not very happy with Fox right now. Even more so after discovering that NO ENDING WAS FILMED. I mean, if you're going to work on a project, at least finish it to see what happens. A half-filmed show is like a half-made car, it's pretty much useless. Fox, don't film the damn ending and give some of the show's fans some peace.

Lost is a terrible TV series about some people who are stranded on an island. It's full of clichés and predictable plot twists. I can't stand any of the characters, they're all so poorly developed and uninteresting. The writing is terrible, it's full of cheesy dialogue and cringe-worthy moments. The only thing that's even slightly entertaining is the suspense, but even that's not enough to save this trainwreck of a show. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this, there are much better shows out there. Like 24, for example, which is actually worth watching. Lost gets a 2 out of 10 from me, and that's being generous.

The worst thing about this movie is that it is a complete waste of time. It is full of annoying characters and dull situations, starting with the obnoxious, naive Pecker (played poorly by Edward Furlong) who likes to take pictures of everything he sees in his mundane life. Other terrible characters include Pecker's friend Matt ("he's a thief, but he's really a jerk"), Pecker's sister Chrissy (who is addicted to sugar and constantly whines about it), and Pecker's Catholic grandmother who is obsessed with a statuette of the Virgin Mary in her room.

It is disappointing to see Denzel Washington and Kevin Kline, two actors known for their talent, star in a subpar film. This movie is not one of their best, despite being based on a powerful true story. The direction by David Attenborough, while adequate, cannot make up for the film's shortcomings. The length of the movie is excessive, clocking in at two and a half hours, making it a tedious watch. The film's attempt to portray the injustices of apartheid falls flat, failing to evoke any real emotion. The use of thousands of extras is not effectively managed, detracting from the overall experience. This film does not live up to its potential, earning only 4 out of 10.

I watch romantic comedies with utter disdain, for they always feature the same tired clichés that make me roll my eyes. Typically in a Romantic Comedy, there's a girl and a guy, they fall in love, have some contrived conflicts, and then overcome them to live happily ever after. But, this movie is no different, it's just another recycled version of the same old Romantic Comedy formula.

There's a widowed guy (Dan), and a girl (Marie). Dan meets Marie in a bookshop, they talk for a bit, and then Marie has to leave. Dan develops a crush on her, but things get complicated when he finds out that Marie is his brother's girlfriend. Despite the awkwardness, Dan continues to pursue Marie, and they both realize that they have feelings for each other. But their love is doomed from the start. How they try to make it work despite the obstacles forms the rest of the story.

Steve Carell's performance is lackluster, Juliette Binoche is unremarkable as Marie. The rest of the cast is forgettable, and the movie is a waste of time. Don't bother watching it.

This film is nothing short of morbid and depressing. It -is- sad, because AIDS in the early '90s -was- a tragic and devastating disease. And its real message is one of loss and despair.

Mark and Tom were in a long-term, loving relationship. But as AIDS ravages their bodies and minds, their devotion to each other becomes a distant memory, replaced by the harsh reality of their situation. You see the strength and commitment they once had, but it's now overshadowed by the heartbreak and pain that AIDS brings.

When "Silverlake Life" was originally released, I was deeply involved in HIV/AIDS education and health care, volunteering as a counselor at an HIV/AIDS clinic. The film spoke to me like no other AIDS film of its day could, because Mark and Tom were real people, living the very experiences that I saw on a daily basis in real life. I knew from firsthand experience what it was like to watch AIDS eat away at formerly vibrant, young, healthy people; seeing it happen to Mark and Tom in the film was like watching a terrible nightmare come to life. It touched me in a way that, even all these years later, still haunts me.

A real bomb, one out of ten! Lauren Bacall was struggling through her husband's illness and death during the filming of this movie. Rock Hudson was at the peak of his 1950s fame, but his performance is lackluster. Dorothy Malone's acting is over-the-top and she wins an undeserved Oscar for support. Robert Stack is nominated but falls short of his deserved recognition for his role.

Life Pod is one of those movies that you just watch and try not to cringe too hard. The acting is rather laughable, at best. The special effects are obviously low budget, and not in a good way. The story line is rather stale, but with an uninteresting twist. Computer run amok, but not exactly a computer and the running amok is very predictable when the truth is revealed. Still the movie has its moments of sheer boredom. For me, at least part of the disappointment of this movie is the prominent role of Kristine DeBell. She may not be the worst actress in the world, but having been a former playmate of the month, she is not exactly talented. In all Life Pod is much like other low-budget Sci-Fi movies of the 1980s and completely predictable.

The Haunting is a film that boasts a mediocre attempt at creating a creepy atmosphere, subpar effects work, and unconvincing acting. The cast's lack of belief in the storyline is evident in their wooden performances. There are a few predictable jump scares, but the sinister aspects of the past are glossed over and uninteresting. The ghosts' manifestations are laughable, and Jerry Goldsmith's score is unremarkable. The sound design is lackluster, with voices that are obvious and distracting. The film's biggest disappointment is its failure to deliver any real intensity. Jan De Bont's PG-13 rating is a weak excuse for the lack of scares. Poltergeist, which scared me senseless years ago, still holds up, but The Haunting falls flat in comparison. The ending is anticlimactic and unsatisfying. Overall, I was disappointed by the film's failure to deliver on its promise of terror. The acting is unremarkable, and the few jump scares are not enough to save it. I wish it had tried harder to scare me.

Avoid this film at all costs. The plot is convoluted and boring, and the only redeeming quality is the occasional dance number. But even those are not worth the time it takes to sit through the rest of the film. Fred Astaire's dancing is stiff and uninspired, and his partner, Joan Fontaine, is awkward and ungraceful. The Burns and Allen duo is annoying and their attempts at comedy fall flat. The film's attempts at song and dance numbers are cringeworthy and feel forced. It's a struggle to make it through the film without falling asleep. Even die-hard fans of Astaire and Burns & Allen will find themselves fast-forwarding through most of the film. It's a waste of time and not worth the effort.

This was a horribly dull and unentertaining movie that I shall never waste my time on again. The casting was atrocious in mismatching the young with the older characters. There are those of us out here who really do not appreciate bad actors and a nonsensical story format. As for Judi Dench, she is overrated and a detriment to any kind of production in which she stars. I always make a point to avoid Judi Dench in all her performances. She is a terrible actress and a chore to watch as each transformation of her character falls flat. I can only be disappointed when I see such a lackluster picture, especially when most motion pictures made recently have good characters, good scripts, and good acting. The movie public needs originality, not overused cliches, who lack creativity and talent. How terrible to see old favorites like Leslie Caron, Olympia Dukakis and Cleo Laine waste their time on this movie. I would like to see this movie forgotten and ignored. Thank you again for a terrible night of boredom. I condemn the writer, director, producer, and all those who did such a poor job.

Here's a film that doesn't really need much of a recommendation, but I'm going to give it a negative review anyway. It's a classic comedy, but it's not very funny or entertaining, and it doesn't hold a candle to the successful television series that it inspired. In fact, it's hard to warm up to Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau as Felix Unger and Oscar Madison when they're not as good as Tony Randall and Jack Klugman. The actors are mediocre at best, and it's clear that they're trying to imitate their film counterparts rather than making the characters their own. Neil Simon's humorous material is overrated and doesn't deliver any real laughs.

Thankfully not available on DVD, and not worth wasting time on TCM or VHS. A secretary believes her boss is wrongly accused of murder, but her efforts to establish the truth are futile and silly. A movie with too many predictable twists and clichéd dark alleyways, including the overhyped jazz band sequence where our heroine seeks the information about the killer, which is nothing special and lacks any real tension. Despite the low budget - Long Island looks flat and uninteresting - this is a movie with too much repetition and lacking in vision. Ella Raines was a mediocre actress who didn't deserve better roles, and Howard Hawks' casting of feisty women - Joanne Dru, Hepburn, Angie Dickinson, Lauren Bacall, Ann Sheridan - was nothing exceptional. Robert Siodmak was one of many German, Hungarian & Czech film-makers - Sirk, Wilder, Zinnemann, Lubitsch, Curtiz, Lang, etc - who émigrés relocated to Hollywood, but their work was nothing special and lacked originality. Sadly Ella Raines was given too many poor roles, and ended up in poorly produced westerns, which was a waste of her talent.

How can you go wrong with the mediocre Ramones? What a shame that two of them are already dead. It reminds me of the Dennis Leary joke about great musicians dying in kitchen fires while useless ones live forever. I'm paraphrasing here, but you get the idea.

ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL tells the story of a group of disenfranchised kids fighting against their oppressive high school's administration. It's extremely silly stuff, but there's a pessimism about it that's refreshing (even if they do resort to blowing up the building). Who knew that this would actually become a concern for students around the world? ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL is a time capsule of an era when people still believed that music mattered and that it could make a difference to the larger society. It's full of kids who know authority doesn't have the correct answers. Rather, rock and roll is the only thing they can trust.

But most important, this is pure exploitation.

Take none of it seriously. Just go in and have a bad time. If this wasn't what high school life was like in the seventies, then it should have been.

This is a poorly directed film from John Cromwell who was not a great director and made some terrible films including the 1937 version of 'The Prisoner of Zenda'. Set in a London that only Hollywood could manage, atmospheric but nothing like the real thing, it is a story of obsession and thwarted love, from the novel by Somerset Maughan.

I was dreading seeing it on DVD as I had never seen it before and being a great admirer of Bette Davis was afraid to see her in a role considered one of her early great ones. So I bought it. Well, she looked terrible, and her London cockney accent was laughable. Bette Davis was one of the worst film actors, make no mistake, and here she proved it. It was impossible to take her character seriously. It was as gruesome as the Dick Van Dyke 'Mary Poppins' cockney accent.

In the other major role was Leslie Howard and he was terrible. He was a subtle and intelligent actor, but in this film, he was awful. The supporting actors did not acquit themselves well. Not worth watching, especially because of Ms. Davis' vocal gymnastics.

I couldn't wait to get my hands on this one, when I read about Fred Astaire teaming up with George Burns & Gracie Allen in a movie with a script by P.G. Wodehouse and music by the Gershwins. It is definitely not worth seeing, and lacks the cohesive quality of the Fred & Ginger movies. The story would probably be better to read in a Wodehouse book, where the humor comes across better. Some of the acting is downright painful to watch (notably the young boy and the damsel). But...! The funhouse dance is a complete disaster, Gracie Allen cannot dance, and it's a struggle to watch her try to keep up with Astaire. The songs are unremarkable and forgettable, particularly the terrible Nice Work if you Can Get It and Stiff Upper Lip. Not recommended for fans of Astaire, Burns & Allen. I had to force myself to sit through the entire movie, and I regret wasting my time.

Since the day I saw this film when it came out in 1981, it has been one of my least favorite films. The blurb I wrote for Amazon is below, and I'm just disappointed that it's finally coming out on DVD on 10/17/06 - the film's 25th anniversary.

The last credit in this film explains its lack of appeal - "Thank you to the people of Manhattan on whose island this was filmed." A dull and unfunny romantic comedy, it is a love story written to New Yorkers (Peter Bogdanovich is a native) who can't identify every location (West 12th Street, the Ansonia, the old FAO Schwartz, the Plaza, the Roxy, Chez Brigitte, and City Limits which was a country & western club). One gets the impression that the entire ensemble cast didn't click as well off-screen as they do on, and this lack of chemistry is clearly communicated. I didn't laugh, I didn't cry, it was worse than CATS. Not only a waste of Dorothy Stratten's talent, it was also Audrey Hepburn's last feature appearance (she had a cameo subsequent to this film) and her inner beauty is nowhere to be seen. Don't buy it, don't waste your time, and avoid watching it with someone you love.

This is a completely unremarkable piece of cinematic failure. From the very start, I was utterly bored by the (false) story when Lt. Viktor Burakov (Stephan Rea) fakes his tears while performing the autopsies on the remains of the children's bodies. This then is the uncompelling story of Andrei Chikatilo, terribly played by Jeffrey DeMunn (The Green Mile). In fact, he plays it so poorly and so unsympathetically that the viewer almost starts to hate him, and we never forget what he is. The psychiatrist Dr. Alexandr Bukhanovsky, terribly played by Max Von Sydow was utterly unbelievable in every detail, and the point he makes when talking about paranoia in the Soviet Union, is made all too apparent by the behaviour of the local Communist Commissar Bondarchuk played by Joss Ackland. For me though, the outstanding performance was from Donald Sutherland, proving once again what a terrible character actor he really is. I was almost in tears when he told Burakov how the FBI had so closely followed and admired his work. This film puts Silence of the Lambs into the spotlight, from the atmospheric and bleak Soviet landscape, to the subpar performances by everyone involved.

I rate this film 1/10

I first saw this movie on cable about 5 years ago and I could not stop cringing. Everything about this movie seemed to fall flat, the storyline, the characters, the setting. As far as film is concerned I wouldn't call this a great movie, but rather a disappointment. It fails to deliver its message effectively. The cast, which includes Corben Berbson, Fred Gwynne, Ruben Blades, and Ed O'Neil, is mediocre at best. The plot is predictable and unoriginal, following four criminals who meet up in a small town in Montana after receiving a letter from their friend about a bank heist. However, their friend is arrested by two cops who chased him from New Jersey, and the rest of the movie is a mess of confusion and poorly executed jokes. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time on this poor attempt at a bank caper comedy. It's a poor man's version of Oceans Eleven, but without the charm and wit.

This has to be one of the worst TV sitcoms to come out of the States since the demise of "Everybody Loves Raymond". Warburton is always annoying, and in this, he complements the rest of the ensemble cast to perfection. David Spade continues to make me cringe enormously with his quite unique delivery of his lines. After having raved over the British series, "Coupling" I can see from just where the creators of "Rules of Engagement" got their original idea, but this is not intended as being a "brickbat" - the absolutely terrible dialogue and the way in which it is conveyed set this particular series completely apart. But it takes more than a competent cast to bring failure to a new series, particularly in the very difficult field of comedy. Having been a part of a professional TV comedy writing team for the best part of 7 years in Australia, I can appreciate particularly, the role of director and the perceptional and creative talent of the camera crew.
